params.text:
• Identify the Stakeholders (history/profile)
  • Identify the issues for each party and their limit
  • Bring together the different elements of the negotiation

Negotiations

Gather the Information

Language in Action
Negotiations: Introduction

Effective negotiation requires a strong foundation of knowledge before entering the discussion. In this module, you'll develop your skills in information gathering, a critical step in any successful negotiation. 

Here's what you'll learn:

1. Identify Stakeholders: Understand who is involved in the negotiation and their history with the issue.

  2. Identify Issues & Limits: Recognize the key issues for each party involved in the negotiation.

  3. Bring it Together: Learn how to consolidate the information you've gathered to develop a comprehensive strategy for the negotiation.
Strategies for Identifying Stakeholders

Successful negotiation hinges on understanding who is involved.

Here are some strategies to identify key stakeholders and gather information about them:
Review the Negotiation Context:
• Analyze the background and nature of the negotiation. This will help you identify the main parties involved and any external groups who might be impacted by the outcome.
Consider Power Dynamics:
• Identify the power dynamics at play. Who has the most leverage or influence in the negotiation? Understanding this will help you predict their behavior and negotiation style.
Research the Parties Involved:
• Research the individuals and companies involved in the negotiation. Look for information about their experience, negotiation history, and any potential biases they might hold.
Identify Decision-Makers:
• Not everyone at the negotiation table will have the authority to make final decisions. Identify who has the ultimate say in the outcome and tailor your communication accordingly.
Identify the Stakeholders: Opinions & Quiz
Please listen to the opinions of three people talking about identifying stakeholders and answer the questions below:

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: When researching stakeholders, it's important to consider their company's financial situation.
Question 2 of 3: Talking to people outside the negotiation team can be a good way to learn about company culture.
Question 3 of 3: Understanding past negotiation attempts can help you predict future challenges.

params.text:
Bryan: "Preparation is key! Research the companies you'll be negotiating with. Look for their annual reports, press releases, and any recent news articles. This can reveal their priorities, financial situation, and potential areas of flexibility."

Anthony: "Don't underestimate the power of informal conversations. Connect with people on the periphery of the negotiation. These conversations can provide valuable insights into company culture, internal politics, and potential decision-makers you might not have been aware of."

Abigail: "Understanding the stakeholders' history with the issue is crucial. Were there previous negotiation attempts? What were the sticking points? Learning from past experiences can help you anticipate challenges and develop effective strategies to overcome them."

params.text: Strategies to Identify Issues & Limits

Negotiation success relies on pinpointing the key issues and understanding each party's limits. 

Here are some strategies to identify key stakeholders and gather information about them:
Active Listening:
• Pay close attention to what the other party is saying, both verbally and nonverbally. Listen for their priorities, concerns, and underlying motivations.
Scenario Planning:
• Consider different scenarios and potential outcomes. What are your own priorities and what are your "limits" - the point beyond which you're not willing to concede?
Open-Ended Questions:
• Use open-ended questions to encourage the other party to elaborate on their needs and expectations. This will help you identify their core issues and potential deal-breakers.
Brainstorming with Colleagues:

• Discuss the negotiation with colleagues who have different perspectives. This brainstorming can help you identify potential issues you might have overlooked and refine your understanding of the other party's limits.

metadata.title: Strategies to Identify Issues & Limits sentences

params.text: Strategies to Consolidate Information

Having gathered information about stakeholders, issues, and limits, it's time to consolidate your findings.

Here are some strategies to bring it all together:
Develop a Negotiation Matrix:

• Create a table that outlines the key stakeholders, their interests (what they want), and their potential concessions (what they might be willing to give up). This visual tool will help you identify areas of potential compromise and collaboration.

Develop a BATNA
(Best Alternative To a Negotiated Agreement):

• Consider your BATNA - your best course of action if no agreement is reached. Having a strong alternative gives you leverage in the negotiation and prevents you from feeling pressured to accept a bad deal.
Prioritize Your Goals:

• Clearly define your priorities and "walk-away points" (the minimum concession you're willing to make). Knowing your bottom line will guide your negotiation strategy and prevent you from accepting unfavorable terms.
BATNA: Interactive Video

params.text: What Would You Say? Read & Quiz
Read each scenario and choose the BEST course of action.

choices.question:
Question 1 of 3: You're negotiating a contract renewal with a key supplier. You've identified their interest in a guaranteed order volume. Your priority is securing a price reduction.
What would you do?
answers:
Create a negotiation matrix to explore how offering a larger order could lead to a discounted price. 

Focus solely on getting the lowest possible price, regardless of order volume. 

Immediately present your desired price reduction without considering the supplier's needs.

choices.question:
Question 2 of 3: You're preparing for a salary negotiation with your manager. You've researched the average salary range for your position and experience level.
What should you do next?
answers:
Define your priorities (desired salary increase) and walk-away point (minimum acceptable raise). 

Present your research findings and demand the highest salary in the range. 

Focus on your accomplishments without mentioning your salary expectations.

choices.question:
Question 3 of 3: You're negotiating a partnership agreement with another company. You've identified potential areas of compromise but are unsure about their BATNA (Best Alternative To a Negotiated Agreement).
What's the best approach?
answers:
Brainstorm with colleagues to consider what their BATNA might be and adjust your strategy accordingly.  

Avoid mentioning BATNA altogether and focus on your own priorities. 

Directly ask the other party to reveal their BATNA.

params.text: Module Summary Quiz
Read each question carefully and choose the BEST answer.

choices.question: Question 1 of 4: Active listening in a negotiation involves:
answers:
Paying close attention to both verbal and nonverbal cues to understand their priorities. 

Interrupting the other party to present your own points. 

Focusing solely on the facts and figures presented by the other party.

choices.question: Question 2 of 4: When using open-ended questions during a negotiation, you aim to:
answers:
Encourage the other party to elaborate on their needs and expectations. 

Get the other party to agree to your pre-determined terms. 

Confirm your assumptions about the other party's position.

choices.question: Question 3 of 4: A negotiation matrix can be helpful for:
answers:
Identifying areas of potential compromise and collaboration between parties. 

Keeping track of technical details exchanged during the negotiation. 

Writing the final contract document outlining the agreed-upon terms.

choices.question: Question 4 of 4: Your BATNA (Best Alternative To a Negotiated Agreement) refers to:
answers:
The course of action you will take if no agreement is reached in the negotiation.

The minimum concessions you are willing to make in the negotiation. 

The concessions you are most likely to obtain from the other party.
